results.adx_keywords: Gambling;Athletics and Sports;Regulation and Deregulation of Industry;Law and Legislation;States (US);American Gaming Assn;Council on Problem Gambling;DraftKings Inc;FanDuel.com;New York State Gaming Commission;Penn Entertainment Inc;United States
results.byline: By Eric Lipton and Kevin Draper
results.title: First Came the Sports Betting Boom. Now Comes the Backlash.
results.abstract: In many U.S. states and across the world, regulators are cracking down on the sports gambling industry, citing harm to the public and, in some cases, to athletes.

media.caption: An advertisement for Caesars Sportsbook last October at Michigan State University.
media.copyright: Stephen Speranza for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Churches (Buildings);Windows;Auctions;Collectors and Collections;Stained Glass;Tiffany;Tiffany, Louis Comfort;Samuel T Freeman & Co (Freeman's);Philadelphia (Pa)
results.title: Sold for a Song, a Church’s Windows Turned Out to Be Tiffany
results.abstract: Two fixtures, which were covered in grime, were sold along with other artifacts by a Philadelphia church’s new owner for $6,000. An auction house estimates they could bring up to $250,000 — each.

media.caption: One of two Tiffany rose windows sets to be auctioned by Freeman’s Auction House in Philadelphia. They were formerly encased high in the walls of what is now the Hickman Temple A.M.E. Church.

results.adx_keywords: Art;Museums;Trees and Shrubs;Content Type: Personal Profile;van Gogh, Vincent;Metropolitan Museum of Art
results.title: Van Gogh and the Consolation of Trees
results.abstract: A revelatory show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art reunites 24 paintings of cypresses and unchains them from their somber associations.

media.caption: 1889 was a very good year for van Goghs: The artist produced “Wheat Field With Cypresses,” left, and “Cypresses,” seen in the conservation center at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. In both, the trees seem to lean against each other.
media.copyright: George Etheredge for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Content Type: Personal Profile;Folk Music;Pop and Rock Music;Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming;Nineteen Hundred Fifties;internal-sub-only;Converse, Elizabeth Eaton (Connie);Greenwich Village (Manhattan, NY);Upper West Side (Manhattan, NY);Manhattan (NYC)
results.title: Before Dylan, There Was Connie Converse. Then She Vanished.
results.abstract: There’s a resurgence of interest in the pioneering singer-songwriter who disappeared when she was 50.

media.caption: Connie Converse in Riverside Park, 1946. It is one of the first known images of Ms. Converse in New York.

results.adx_keywords: Pizza;Pop-Up Stores and Restaurants;Ovens and Stoves;New York City
results.title: New York’s Most Inventive Pizzas Are Cooked Up at Pop-Ups
results.abstract: With a new breed of portable ovens and an anything-goes spirit, roving pizzaiolos are turning out impressive pies at bars, breweries and events.

media.caption: Last week, Wizard Hat finished a two-year stint at a Brooklyn bar. In June, it will pop up inside a bakery.
media.copyright: DeSean McClinton-Holland for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Deserts;Road Trips;Telescopes and Observatories;Mummies and Mummification;Atacama Desert;Chile
results.byline: By Maggie Shipstead and Anthony Cotsifas
results.title: What Survives in the Atacama Desert?
results.abstract: In Chile, a writer takes a road trip through one of the world’s driest places — a landscape that preserves remnants of the dead.

media.caption: The Tara Salt Flat sits at 14,000 feet in the northern Chilean Andes, at the eastern edge of the Atacama Desert. Some 250 miles to the west lies the Pacific Ocean and, in between, a vast, near rainless interior.

results.adx_keywords: Prostate Cancer;Tests (Medical);Prostate Specific Antigen;Men and Boys;Tumors;Surgery and Surgeons;Elderly;Age, Chronological;Preventive Medicine;New England Journal of Medicine;Great Britain;United States
results.title: Too Many Older Men Are Still Screened for Prostate Cancer
results.abstract: Most have low-risk cancers and rarely benefit from treatment, a new study finds. Actively monitoring the condition is often the best choice.

media.caption: Joe Loree wanted to avoid the aggressive treatment for prostate cancer that he had seen his brother and friend undergo, and opted for a more conservative approach called active surveillance.

results.adx_keywords: Birthdays;Social Media;Parties (Social);Children and Childhood;Parenting;High Net Worth Individuals;internal-sub-only;Los Angeles (Calif)
results.title: It’s a Toddler’s Party. How About a $75,000 Budget?
results.abstract: In Los Angeles, children’s birthday celebrations have spiraled into mini-weddings.

media.caption: A seventh-birthday party in Los Angeles.
media.copyright: Leesa Zelken/Send in The Clowns LA

results.title: Welcome to the Era of Very Earnest Parenting
results.abstract: Millennials, guided by influencers like Dr. Becky and the women behind Big Little Feelings, are trying to deal with their children in a new way.

results.adx_keywords: World War II (1939-45);Women and Girls;Content Type: Personal Profile;American Red Cross
results.title: My Mother Returned From World War II a Changed Woman
results.abstract: In her World War II photographs and those of her friends, my mother is laughing and bright-eyed in every single one. I almost don’t recognize her.

media.caption: Phyllis McLaughlin, a volunteer with the Red Cross Clubmobile Service, during World War II.

results.adx_keywords: Dancing;Travel and Vacations;Pilgrimages;Flamenco (Dance);Christians and Christianity;Religion and Belief;Roman Catholic Church;Andalusia (Spain);Seville (Spain);Spain
results.byline: By Kevin Faingnaert and Anna Hart
results.title: Flamenco and Fervor: Inside Spain’s El Rocío Pilgrimage
results.abstract: The annual spectacle, featuring fanciful caravans and riders on horseback, is arguably the most potent visual representation of Andalusian culture.

media.caption: Pilgrims on horseback ride through Coto Doñana National Park.

results.adx_keywords: Olympic Games (2024);Swimming;Water Pollution;Sewers and Sewage;Seine River (France);Paris (France);Marne River (France)
results.byline: By Catherine Porter and James Hill
results.title: Olympic Swimming in the Seine? How Paris Is Remaking a River.
results.abstract: Organizers of the 2024 Summer Games promised a waterway clean enough for Olympic swimmers and then Parisians to swim in. The job was bigger than anyone knew.

media.caption: Paddlers on the Seine in December. In 2024, the river will serve as the venue for Olympic triathlon and distance swimming events.

results.adx_keywords: Cooking and Cookbooks;Salmon;Content Type: Service
results.title: Kenji López-Alt’s Tips for Juicy, Crisp-Skinned Salmon? Add Salt and Wait.
results.abstract: Dry-brining fillets‌ works wonders, making cooking a breeze and yielding unforgettably succulent results.

media.caption: Dry-brining reduces moisture in salmon, reducing spatter in the pan.
media.copyright: Ryan Liebe for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Maggie Ruggiero.

results.adx_keywords: Automobiles;Electric and Hybrid Vehicles;Automobile Service and Charging Stations;Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline;Politics and Government;Batteries;Global Warming;Electric Light and Power;Greenhouse Gas Emissions;Labor and Jobs;Air Pollution;International Trade and World Market;audio-neutral-informative;Tesla Motors Inc;Volkswagen AG;Volvo Car Corp;Norway
results.title: In Norway, the Electric Vehicle Future Has Already Arrived
results.abstract: About 80 percent of new cars sold in Norway are battery-powered. As a result, the air is cleaner, the streets are quieter and the grid hasn’t collapsed. But problems with unreliable chargers persist.

media.caption: About 80 percent of new-car sales in Norway were electric last year, putting the country at the vanguard of the shift to emissions-free vehicles.
media.copyright: David B. Torch for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Ears and Hearing;Hearing Aids;Youth
results.title: Hearing Aids Are Changing. Their Users Are, Too.
results.abstract: As more young people risk hearing loss, over-the-counter hearing aids are providing new options, but also confusing choices.

media.copyright: Lauren Segal for The New York Times
